Typedef Documentation

typedef struct cvmx_tim_entry_chunk cvmx_tim_entry_chunk_t

Each timer bucket contains a list of work queue entries to schedule when the timer fires.

The list is implemented as a linked list of blocks. Each block contains an array of work queue entries followed by a next block pointer. Since these blocks are dynamically allocated off of a hardware memory pool, there actual size isn't known compile time. The next block pointer is stored in the last 8 bytes of the memory block.

static cvmx_tim_status_t cvmx_tim_add_entry ( cvmx_wqe_t *  work_entry,
uint64_t  ticks_from_now,
cvmx_tim_delete_t *  delete_info 
) [inline, static]

Add a work queue entry to the timer.

Parameters:
work_entry Work queue entry to add.
ticks_from_now 
delete_info Optional pointer where to store information needed to delete the timer entry. If non NULL information needed to delete the timer entry before it fires is stored here. If you don't need to be able to delete the timer, pass NULL.
Returns:
Result return code
static cvmx_tim_status_t cvmx_tim_delete_entry ( cvmx_tim_delete_t *  delete_info  )  [inline, static]

Delete a timer entry scheduled using cvmx_tim_add_entry.

Deleting a timer will fail if it has already triggered or might be in progress. The actual state of the work queue entry isn't changed. You need to dispose of it properly.

Parameters:
delete_info Structure passed to cvmx_tim_add_entry to store the information needed to delete a timer entry.
Returns:
CVMX_TIM_STATUS_BUSY if the timer was not deleted, otherwise CVMX_TIM_STATUS_SUCCESS.

Gets the internal FPA pool data structure for timer pool.

timer_pool pointer to timer fpa pool structure where data gets copied

int cvmx_tim_setup ( uint64_t  tick,
uint64_t  max_ticks 
)

Setup a timer for use.

Must be called before the timer can be used.

Parameters:
tick Time between each bucket in microseconds. This must not be smaller than 1024/(clock frequency in MHz).
max_ticks The maximum number of ticks the timer must be able to schedule in the future. There are guaranteed to be enough timer buckets such that: number of buckets >= max_ticks.
Returns:
Zero on success. Negative on error. Failures are possible if the number of buckets needed is too large or memory allocation fails for creating the buckets.
void cvmx_tim_shutdown ( void   ) 

Stop the timer.

After this the timer must be setup again before use.

void cvmx_tim_start ( void   ) 

Start the hardware timer processing.

void cvmx_tim_stop ( void   ) 

Stop the hardware timer processing.

Timers stay configured.
